column34: Illustrates the cognitive processes involved in programming. Many cognitive processes are involved, not just mathematical reasoning. Different processes are at work depending on the task. For programming, holistic processing is important, not just viewing individual statements. The opposite is true if one is concerned with syntax. The study shows a sign difference in the regression coefficient between general and mathematical reasoning for syntax although it is generally assumed that the two have a relationship; the reason is not understood. While mathematical reasoning is highly correlated with overall programming ability, is is relatively insignificant for the more fundamental aspects of programming, indicating that maths reasoning is related more closely to primary abilities than the other cognitive processes tested, or that the others are a foundation for mathematical reasoning.

The paper asks what looping strategy people naturally use, whether their programs will be more correct when the language has a looping construct they prefer, and whether the provided looping construct influences program correctness. The paper finds that:
- there is a stronger preference for the READ/PROCESS looping strategy when planning a program (among those whose strategy could be determined),
- there is also a stronger preference for READ/PROCESS when implementing a program,
- a READ/PROCESS looping construct in the language is associated with fewer errors,
- people make fewer errors when they can use their preferred looping construct,
- errors, sensitivity to the provided looping construct, and preference for looping construct can vary with level of experience.
The paper implicitly attempts to generalise the findings regarding looping to cognitive strategies in programming in general.

column34: The paper investigates code comprehension. It constructs a model/theory of code comprehension based on several existing models/theories and empirical results. The integrated code comprehension model includes the components 1) Program Model, 2) Situation Model, 3) Top-Down Model (Domain Model), and 4) Knowledge Base. The first three are comprehension processes while the third is necessary for building the first three (the individual builds the three models in their mind). The paper validates the model by using a think-aloud protocol to observe industry practitioners performing code comprehension tasks on real industry code. The paper finds that participants worked on all three model levels and that switches between model levels can occur as the result of the maintenance engineer generating hypotheses regarding the code while trying to comprehend it. Differences and similarities between participants are described and discussed. The paper finds that 1. programmers use a multi-level approach to comprehension, frequently switching between comprehension models, 2. maintenance activities can be described by a distinct small set of cognition processes which aggregate into higher level processes, and 3. current practice of documentation and coding does not encourage efficient understanding because knowledge is compartmentalised by type of document without the cross-references needed to support programmers' cognitive needs. The paper derives information needs from the observations and proposes capabilities that tools should have to support comprehension.

- The questions ask the participant to, e.g. match procedure names to the procedures they call, listing procedure names, writing descriptions of goals (of procedures and entire program), labelling code segments, listing names used for the same data objects in different program units, listing important variable names, filling in names of program units in a program outline, matching variable names to procedures where they occur, and indicating physical location of invariant program parts.

column34: The paper investigates five characteristics of mental representations of programs in novice and expert programmers. In the study, participants read a short program and then have to perform tasks that each tries to elicit whether their mental representation has a certain characteristic. For example, two questions try to determine whether the participants have a hierarchical, layered structure (the stimulus program had a clear hierarchical, layered structure in the form of nested procedures and functions). The performance on each question was evaluated by two independent judges. The results indicate that the five abstract characteristics exist in the mental representations of expert programmers but novice programmers do not show them to the same degree. Several detailed findings and discussion is given in the paper.
